title: Helldivers 2 is locking out players who use older CPUs
snippets: Players of Helldivers 2 with older CPUs have encountered issues running the game due to a requirement for AVX2 (Advanced Vector Extensions) support, a feature present in CPUs since 2013. This requirement comes from the game's developer, Arrowhead Game Studios, and publisher, Sony.
summary: Players of the video game Helldivers 2, developed by Arrowhead Game Studios and published by Sony, are experiencing issues if they have older CPUs lacking AVX2 support. AVX2, a feature in CPUs since 2013, is necessary to run the game.

title: A genetic tree as a movie: Moving beyond the still portrait of ancestry
snippets: Researchers have developed a statistical method that allows individuals to view their family tree in a dynamic movie format, showcasing the global movements of their ancestors over time. This innovative approach can also be applied to track the spread of diseases and analyze animal migration patterns across different geographic areas.
summary: Researchers have created a new statistical method that transforms family trees into dynamic movies, illustrating the global movements of ancestors over time. This method can also track disease spread and analyze animal migration patterns across various regions.

title: Melting ice, more rain drive Southern Ocean cooling
snippets: Researchers have discovered that 60% of the discrepancy between predicted and actual ocean temperatures around Antarctica over several decades is due to increased meltwater and rain.
summary: Researchers found that increased meltwater and rain account for 60% of the unexpected difference in predicted versus actual ocean temperatures around Antarctica over many years.

title: Cartilage and bone development: Three paths to skeleton formation
snippets: Researchers have found that in vertebrates, skeletal cells from various body regions originate from different precursor cells and have distinct gene regulation. This discovery could explain vertebrates' evolutionary success by showing how skeletal diversity is genetically programmed.
summary: Researchers discovered that vertebrates' skeletal cells come from various precursor cells and have unique gene regulation, depending on their body region. This finding suggests that genetic programming for skeletal diversity may contribute to vertebrates' evolutionary success.

title: Terahertz imaging: Breakthrough in non-invasive cochlear visualization
snippets: Researchers have developed a non-invasive method using terahertz (THz) imaging to visualize the cochlear structures in mice, enabling high-resolution diagnostics. This technology allows for 3D reconstructions of the inner ear, potentially improving the diagnosis of hearing loss and other conditions. The advancement could lead to the creation of miniaturized THz imaging devices, enhancing diagnostic speed, accuracy, and patient outcomes in various medical fields, including hearing loss and cancer.
summary: Researchers have created a non-invasive technique using terahertz imaging to visualize mouse cochlear structures, offering high-resolution diagnostics. This method enables 3D inner ear reconstructions, potentially improving hearing loss diagnosis. The technology may lead to smaller THz imaging devices, increasing diagnostic speed and accuracy in medical fields like hearing loss and cancer.

title: We must not ignore eugenics in our genetics curriculum, says professor
snippets: Biology professor Mark Peifer from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill advocates for the inclusion of eugenics in college genetics curriculums. He believes this will help scientists counteract the misuse of science for political purposes by encouraging them to speak up.
summary: Mark Peifer, a biology professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, recommends adding eugenics to college genetics courses. He argues this will prepare scientists to address and oppose the political misuse of scientific concepts.
